node.statement:
SECOND REPAIR â€” NODE 1.6.2.10: Uniform-in-eps L^p bounds for Wick power Besov norms under mu_eps.

CLAIM: For each k in {1,2,3}, for any delta > 0 and any p >= 1, there exists a constant C(k, delta, p) > 0, INDEPENDENT of eps, such that

  E_{mu_eps}[ || :phi_eps^k:_{C_eps} ||_{C^{-k/2-delta}(T^3)}^p ] <= C(k, delta, p)

for all eps > 0 sufficiently small.

PROOF: This is a CONSEQUENCE of the construction of the Phi^4_3 measure itself. The construction (Hairer 2014, Gubinelli-Hofmanova 2019, Mourrat-Weber 2017) proceeds by:

(i) Defining the regularized measures mu_eps on C^{-1/2-delta}(T^3), each carrying enhanced data (phi_eps, :phi_eps^2:_{C_eps}, :phi_eps^3:_{C_eps}).

(ii) Establishing UNIFORM-IN-EPS moment bounds for the enhanced data in Besov spaces. Specifically, the stochastic estimates (Hairer 2014, Section 10; Gubinelli-Hofmanova 2019, Proposition 3.1) show that for every p >= 1 and delta > 0:

  sup_{eps > 0} E_{mu_eps}[ || :phi_eps^k:_{C_eps} ||_{C^{-k/2-delta}}^p ] < infinity.

(iii) Using these uniform bounds to establish TIGHTNESS of the family {mu_eps} (viewed as measures on the enhanced data space), and extracting a convergent subsequence whose limit is mu.

The uniform L^p bounds in (ii) are not an afterthought; they are THE CORE of the construction. Without them, tightness fails and the limiting measure does not exist.

CRUCIAL POINT: These bounds concern the Wick powers :phi_eps^k:_{C_eps} treated as SINGLE distributional objects in C^{-k/2-delta}(T^3). At no point do we decompose Wick powers into raw powers (which would introduce divergent C_eps(0) terms). The bounds are established by stochastic-analytic methods (regularity structures / paracontrolled distributions / Schauder estimates) that keep the Wick renormalization intact.

This node depends on node 1.6.1 (validated), which establishes that the Wick powers are well-defined elements of the stated Besov spaces.

REFERENCES: Hairer (2014), Section 10 (bounds on the stochastic objects); Gubinelli-Hofmanova (2019), Proposition 3.1 (uniform estimates for regularized model); Mourrat-Weber (2017), Theorem 1.1 (global well-posedness and moment bounds); node 1.6.1 (validated).
